*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u202f28*.proposition: Under *G.L. c. 208, § 28*, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and a determination that modification is in the **best interests of the child**.

*G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u202f20*.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, *Sophia Reynolds* (“Plaintiff” or “Mother”), and respectfully moves this Honorable Court, pursuant to *G.L. c. 208, § 28* and *G.L. c. 209C, § 20*, to modify the existing custody order entered on **May 15, 2018** by this Court, and for reasons states as follows:

*G.L. c. 209C*.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to *G.L. c. 209C*, *G.L. c. 208, § 28*, and *Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 12* and *25* as this Court issued the original custody judgment and both parties continue to reside in Massachusetts.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a parent seeking modification must demonstrate (a) a material change since the prior order, and (b) that the requested change will promote the child’s welfare and stability. *See, e.g.*, **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); **White v. LaDue**, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 430 (1997).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a relocation/removal case decided in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion does not articulate or apply the familiar Massachusetts two‑prong modification standard (material and substantial change plus best interests/welfare and stability). Instead, it interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and sets out the “real advantage” test for removal as part of the original custody determination. Therefore it does not support the claimed proposition about standards for modification actions.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general modification standard case. The opinion frames the issue solely in terms of whether removal is in the children’s best interests (“upon cause shown” = best interests), and it does not articulate or apply a two-part requirement that a party seeking modification must show (1) a material change in circumstances and (2) that the change promotes the child’s welfare and stability. The ALI quotation about relocation being a “substantial change in circumstances” is descriptive of the ALI Principles, not an adoption of a general Massachusetts modification test, so this case does not affirm the proposition claimed.

Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

White v. LaDue, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 430 (1.relevant_excerpt: The case of Aronson v. Brookline Rent Control Bd., 19 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Developmental needs of the child and improved circumstances of a parent—such as availability of suitable housing—may constitute such a change. *See* **Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006); **Schuler v. Schuler**, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case focused on Yannas’s ‘real advantage’ test and the impact of a custodial parent’s remarriage on a removal request. It does discuss best interests factors such as schooling, housing quality, and developmental/transition issues, but only as they bear on whether to permit removal—not as examples of ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ justifying modification of custody or parenting time. The only ‘change in circumstances’ analysis concerns the mother’s remarriage post‑divorce, not general developmental needs or improved parental housing, so the case does not clearly support the proposition as framed.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: This opinion is about modification of alimony and child support based on the payor’s financial circumstances (income, earning capacity, and assets) and does not discuss the developmental needs of the child or changes such as improved housing for a parent. Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28 … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

*G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u202f31*.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the controlling standard, requiring the Court to consider the totality of circumstances, including emotional bonds, continuity, and parental fitness. *See* **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Care & Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the controlling standard, requiring the Court to consider the totality of circumstances, including emotional bonds, continuity, and parental fitness. *See* **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Care & Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reaffirms that the controlling standard in custody determinations is the “best interests of the child,” traces its historical roots, and explains that all relevant factors must be weighed. It emphasizes stability, continuity of placement, the child’s relationships with caregivers, and parental capacity to meet the child’s needs, thus reflecting a totality‑of‑circumstances approach that includes emotional bonds and parental fitness. The discussion is fully consistent with the proposition for which it is cited.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since…. The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the controlling standard, requiring the Court to consider the totality of circumstances, including emotional bonds, continuity, and parental fitness. *See* **G.L. c. 208, § 31**; **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Care & Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses that after finding parental unfitness, the judge must still address placement options based on the children’s best interests, and criticizes the lower court for not adequately considering factors such as sibling relationships, maintaining children within the natural family, and the impact of separations. It characterizes the parental fitness and best interests tests as overlapping and requires findings that demonstrate the children’s best interests have been considered. This aligns with the proposition that best interests is the controlling standard requiring a totality-of-circumstances analysis, including emotional bonds, continuity, and parental fitness.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’… In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests… The judge’s findings… are deficient in that he failed to address… the importance of the sibling relationship, and whether placement of all three children with the paternal grandparents would be in the best interests of the children.”}

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether courts may consider the parents’ reasonableness and cooperation, especially when both assent to a modification that better serves the child’s needs. Rosenberg v. Merida deals with: (1) crediting Social Security disability dependency benefits toward child support; (2) attachment of assets; and (3) standards for modifying custody (material and substantial change, best interests, need for specific findings). Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’”

Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case…”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u202f6.proposition: The Massachusetts statutory framework provides discretion to the Court to alter custody and parenting time to adapt to evolving circumstances and maintain consistency and stability in the child’s upbringing. *See* **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 20**; *See also* **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Massachusetts statutory framework provides discretion to the Court to alter custody and parenting time to adapt to evolving circumstances and maintain consistency and stability in the child’s upbringing. *See* **G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 209C, § 20**; *See also* **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses statutory requirements (particularly G.L. c. 208, § 31) for written findings in custody orders where there is a history of domestic violence and emphasizes the need to consider domestic violence explicitly in custody determinations. It does not, however, address or articulate a general principle about the court’s ongoing discretion to alter custody and parenting time to adapt to evolving circumstances and promote consistency and stability. The remand here concerns the adequacy of findings, not the flexible, continuing-modification authority described in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ … Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31.”
